message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest celiac disease, which can cause malabsorption leading to weight loss and pale conjunctiva, as well as skin rashes. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies are used to help diagnose celiac disease. Increased serum lipase suggests pancreatitis, esophageal webs suggest Plummer-Vinson syndrome, and oocysts on acid-fast stain suggest Cryptosporidium infection, none of which fit with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest celiac disease, which is characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, loose stools, weight loss, and a pruritic skin rash. Conjunctival pallor and inflammation of the corners of the mouth suggest iron-deficiency anemia. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies are commonly used to confirm the diagnosis of celiac disease. Increased serum lipase would suggest pancreatitis, which is not supported by the patient's symptoms. Esophageal webs would suggest Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which is not supported by the patient's symptoms. Oocysts on acid-fast stain would suggest cryptosporidiosis, which is not supported by the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest celiac disease, which can be confirmed by testing for IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Increased serum lipase suggests acute pancreatitis, esophageal webs suggest Plummer-Vinson syndrome, and oocysts on acid-fast stain suggest cryptosporidiosis.

Increased serum lipase suggests pancreatitis while esophageal webs suggest Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Oocysts on acid-fast stain suggest Cryptosporidiosis.

Increased serum lipase suggests pancreatic disease, esophageal webs suggest Plummer-Vinson syndrome, and oocysts on acid-fast stain suggest cryptosporidiosis.

The symptoms, especially the skin rash, bloating after meals, and diarrhea suggest celiac disease, which can be confirmed with IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Increased serum lipase would suggest pancreatitis, esophageal webs would suggest Plummer-Vinson syndrome, and oocysts on acid-fast stain would suggest cryptosporidiosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including bloating after meals, loose bowel movements, and skin rash, suggest celiac disease. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies are commonly used to diagnose celiac disease. Increased serum lipase suggests pancreatic inflammation. Esophageal webs suggests Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Oocysts on acid-fast stain suggest Cryptosporidiosis. None of these options are closely related to the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms consistent with celiac disease, including bloating, loose stools, and skin rash. The conjunctival pallor and inflammation of the corners of the mouth suggest iron deficiency anemia. Increased serum lipase suggests pancreatitis, which is not likely in this case. Esophageal webs suggest Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which is not consistent with the patient’s symptoms. Oocysts on acid-fast stain suggest Cryptosporidiosis, which is not likely in this case. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies are used to diagnose celiac disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest celiac disease, which is characterized by abdominal pain, bloating, loose stools, and skin rash. The conjunctival pallor suggests anemia, and the inflammation of the corners of the mouth suggests angular stomatitis. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies are commonly used to diagnose celiac disease. Esophageal webs would suggest Plummer-Vinson syndrome, and increased serum lipase and oocysts on acid-fast stain suggest other conditions that are not consistent with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bloating, loose bowel movements, and weight loss suggest malabsorption. The pruritic skin rash on the shoulders suggests dermatitis herpetiformis, which is associated with celiac disease. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies are typically elevated in patients with celiac disease. Increased serum lipase suggests pancreatitis. Esophageal webs suggest Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Oocysts on acid-fast stain suggest Cryptosporidium infection.
